standard_metadata.standard_description: Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities. Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology

question.content: A worker bee has a mass of $0.00011 \text{ kg}$.  **Choose the best approximation of the mass of a worker bee.**   An African elephant has a mass of $8139 \text{ kg}$.  **Choose the best approximation of the mass of an African elephant.**   **Approximately how many times as large is the mass of an African elephant as the mass of a worker bee?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the mass of a worker bee.  $\phantom{\approx }0.00011\text{ kg}$  $\approx 0.0001\text{ kg}$  $\approx1 \cdot 10^{-4}\text{ kg}$
Next, let's approximate the mass of an African elephant.  $\phantom{\approx }8139\text{ kg}$  $\approx 8000\text{ kg}$  $\approx8 \cdot 10^{3}\text{ kg}$

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times greater the mass of an African elephant is than the mass of a worker bee.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{8\cdot10^{3}}{1\cdot10^{-4}}$  $=\dfrac{8}{1} \cdot \dfrac{10^{3}}{10^{-4}}$

question.content: Peggy the Pig built a house of sticks. The stick-house can withstand wind speeds up to $47 \text{ km}$ per hour.  **Choose the best approximation of the highest wind speed that Peggy's stick-house can withstand.**   Patricia the Pig built a very strong house of steel. The steel-house can withstand wind speeds up to $4928 \text{ km}$ per hour.  **Choose the best approximation of the highest wind speed that Patricia's steel-house can withstand.**   **In terms of ability to withstand wind speed, approximately how many times as strong is Patricia's steel-house  as Peggy's stick-house?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the highest wind speed that Peggy's stick-house can withstand.  $\phantom{\approx }47\text{ km}$ per hour  $\approx 50\text{ km}$ per hour  $\approx5 \cdot 10^{1}\text{ km}$ per hour

Next, let's approximate the highest wind speed that Patricia's steel-house can withstand.  $\phantom{=}4928\text{ km}$ per hour  $\approx 5000\text{ km}$ per hour  $\approx5 \cdot 10^{3}\text{ km}$ per hour

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times stronger Patricia's steel-house  is than Peggy's stick-house.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{5\cdot10^{3}}{5\cdot10^{1}}$  $=\dfrac{5}{5} \cdot \dfrac{10^{3}}{10^{1}}$  $=1 \cdot 10^2$

question.content: An average human stride is  $1.44 \text{ m}$ long.  **Choose the best approximation of the length of a human stride.**   A marathon is $42{,}195 \text{ m}$ long.  **Choose the best approximation of the length of a marathon.**   **Approximately how many strides does it take to complete a marathon?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the length of a human stride.  $\phantom{\approx }1.44\text{ m}$  $\approx1\text{ m}$  $\approx1 \cdot 10^{0}\text{ m}$
Next, let's approximate the length of a marathon.  $\phantom{=}42{,}195\text{ m}$  $\approx 40{,}000\text{ m}$  $\approx4 \cdot 10^{4}\text{ m}$
Now, let's divide to approximate how many strides it takes to complete a marathon.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{4\cdot10^{4}}{1\cdot10^{0}}$ strides  $=\dfrac{4}{1} \cdot \dfrac{10^{4}}{10^{0}}$ strides
$=4 \cdot 10^4$ strides

question.content: Liam's mass is $102.1 \text{ kg}$.  **Choose the best approximation of Liam's mass.**   Earth has an estimated mass of $5{,}972{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000 \text{ kg}$.  **Choose the best approximation of the Earth's mass.**   **Approximately how many times as large is the Earth's mass as Liam's mass?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate Liam's mass.  $\phantom{\approx}102.1\text{ kg}$  $\approx 100\text{ kg}$  $\approx1 \cdot 10^2\text{ kg}$
Now, let's divide to approximate how many times greater the Earth's mass is than Liam's mass.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{6\cdot10^{24}}{1\cdot10^{2}}$  $=\dfrac{6}{1} \cdot \dfrac{10^{24}}{10^2}$

question.content: The Mississippi River flows at a rate of $16{,}790$ cubic meters per second.  **Choose the best approximation of the flow rate of the Mississippi River.**   The Gulf of Mexico has an estimated volume of $2{,}434{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000$ cubic meters.  **Choose the best approximation of the volume of the Gulf of Mexico.**   **Approximately how many seconds would it take for the Mississippi River to fill the volume of the Gulf of Mexico?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the flow rate of the Mississippi River.  $\phantom{\approx}16{,}790$ cubic meters per second  $\approx 20{,}000$ cubic meters per second  $\approx2 \cdot 10^4$ cubic meters per second

Next, let's approximate the volume of the Gulf of Mexico.  $\phantom{\approx}2{,}434{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000$ cubic meters  $\approx2{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000$ cubic meters  $\approx2\cdot10^{15}$ cubic meters

Now, let's divide to approximate how many seconds it would take for the Mississippi River to fill the volume of the Gulf of Mexico.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{2\cdot10^{15}}{2\cdot10^{4}}$ seconds  $=\dfrac{2}{2} \cdot \dfrac{10^{15}}{10^4}$ seconds
$= 1 \cdot 10^{11}$ seconds

question.content: In $2014$, the population of the United States was about $318{,}900{,}000$ people.  **Choose the best approximation of the United States population in $2014$.**   In $2014$, the population of the world was about $7{,}125{,}000{,}000$ people.  **Choose the best approximation of the world population in $2014$.**   **Approximately how many times as large was the world population as the United States population in $2014$?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the population of the United States in $2014$.  $\phantom{\approx }318{,}900{,}000$ people  $\approx 300{,}000{,}000$ people  $\approx3 \cdot 10^{8}$ people
Next, let's approximate the population of the world in $2014$.  $\phantom{=}7{,}125{,}000{,}000$ people  $\approx 7{,}000{,}000{,}000$ people  $\approx7 \cdot 10^{9}$ people

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times larger the world population was than the United States population in $2014$.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{7\cdot10^{9}}{3\cdot10^{8}}$  $=\dfrac{7}{3} \cdot \dfrac{10^{9}}{10^{8}}$  $\approx2 \cdot 10^1$
$\approx 20$

question.content: There are about $31{,}500{,}000$ seconds in a year.     **Choose the best approximation of the number of seconds in a year.**   Light travels at a rate of about $9{,}460{,}528{,}400{,}000{,}000 \text{ m}$ per year.  **Choose the best approximation of how many meters light travels per year.**   **Approximately how many meters does light travel per second?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the number of seconds in a year.  $\phantom{\approx }31{,}500{,}000$ seconds  $\approx 32{,}000{,}000$ seconds  $\approx3 \cdot 10^7$ seconds

Next, let's approximate the number of meters light travels in a year.  $\phantom{\approx}9{,}460{,}528{,}400{,}000{,}000$ meters  $\approx9{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000$ meters  $\approx9\cdot10^{15}$ meters

Now, let's divide to approximate how many meters light travels per second.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{9\cdot10^{15}}{3\cdot10^{7}}$ meters per second  $=\dfrac{9}{3} \cdot \dfrac{10^{15}}{10^7}$ meters per second
$\approx 3 \cdot 10^8$ meters per second

question.content: Each page of a document requires $8113 \text{ B}$ (bytes).   **Choose the best approximation of the number of bytes required for a page of a document.**   Rhonda has a USB drive that can hold $8{,}000{,}000{,}000\text{ B}$.  **Choose the best approximation of the number of bytes that Rhonda's USB drive can hold.**   **Approximately how many pages can Rhonda's USB drive hold?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the number of bytes required for a page of a document.  $\phantom{\approx }8113\text{ B}$  $\approx 8000\text{ B}$  $\approx8 \cdot 10^{3}\text{ B}$
Next, let's approximate the number of bytes that Rhonda's USB drive can hold.  $\phantom{=}8{,}000{,}000{,}000\text{ B}$  $=8 \cdot 10^{9}\text{ B}$
Now, let's divide to approximate how many pages Rhonda's USB drive can hold.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{8\cdot10^{9}}{8\cdot10^{3}}$ pages  $=\dfrac{8}{8} \cdot \dfrac{10^{9}}{10^{3}}$ pages
$=1\cdot 10 ^{6}$ pages

question.content: Approximately $1{,}000{,}000$ people cross the Shibuya Crossing intersection each day.  **Choose the best approximation of the number of people that cross Shibuya Crossing each day.**   There are $1440$ minutes in each day.  **Choose the best approximation of the number of minutes in each day.**   **Approximately how many people cross Shibuya Crossing each minute?**

hints.content: First, let's approximate the number of people that cross Shibuya Crossing each day.  $\phantom{=}1{,}000{,}000$ people   $=1 \cdot 10^{6}$ people
Next, let's approximate the number of minutes in each day.  $\phantom{\approx }1440$ minutes  $\approx 1000$ minutes  $\approx1 \cdot 10^{3}$ minutes

Now, let's divide to approximate how many people cross Shibuya Crossing each minute.  $\phantom{=} \dfrac{1\cdot10^{6}}{1\cdot10^{3}}$ people per minute  $=\dfrac{1}{1} \cdot \dfrac{10^{6}}{10^{3}}$ people per minute
$=1 \cdot 10 ^{3}$ people per minute

question.content: The diameter of a human red blood cell is $0.000009 \text{ m}$. The diameter of a cold virus is $0.00000003 \text{ m}$.   **Approximately how many times as large is the diameter of a red blood cell as the diameter of a cold virus?**

hints.content: First, let's estimate the diameter of a red blood cell.  $\phantom{=}0.000009 \text{ m}$    $=9 \cdot 10^{-6}\text{ m}$
Next, let's estimate the diameter of a cold virus.   $\phantom{\approx}0.00000003 \text{ m}$    $=3 \cdot 10^{-8}\text{ m}$

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times greater the diameter of a red blood cell is than the diameter of a cold virus.  $\phantom{=}\dfrac{9\cdot10^{-6}}{3\cdot10^{-8}}$  $=3\cdot\dfrac{10^{-6}}{10^{-8}}$  $=3 \cdot10^2$

question.content: Harvey Porter is a wizard.  He waved his wand and made a grain of sand that had a diameter of $0.00002 \text{ m}$  grow to a diameter $0.006 \text{ m}$.    **Approximately how many times as large is the diameter of the grain of sand now as it was before Harvey Porter waved his wand?**

hints.content: First, let's estimate the new diameter of the grain of sand.  $\phantom{=}0.006 \text{ m}$    $=6 \cdot 10^{-3}\text{ m}$
Next, let's estimate the original diameter of the grain of sand.   $\phantom{=}0.00002 \text{ m}$    $=2 \cdot 10^{-5} \text{ m}$

Now, let's divide to find out how many times greater the diameter of the grain of sand is now than it was before Harvey Porter waved his wand.  $\phantom{=}\dfrac{6\cdot10^{-3}}{2\cdot10^{-5}}$  $=\dfrac{6}{2}\cdot\dfrac{10^{-3}}{10^{-5}}$

question.content: Charlotte's annual salary is $29{,}354$ dollars. She is hoping to win the World Lottery which has a grand prize of $6{,}156{,}782{,}221$ dollars.   **Approximately how many times as large is the World Lottery's grand prize as Charlotte's annual salary?**

hints.content: First, let's estimate the World Lottery's grand prize.  $\phantom{\approx}6{,}156{,}782{,}221$ dollars  $\approx6{,}000{,}000{,}000$ dollars  $\approx6 \cdot 10^{9}$ dollars
Next, let's estimate Charlotte's salary.   $\phantom{\approx}29{,}354$ dollars  $\approx 30{,}000$ dollars  $\approx3 \cdot 10^{4}$ dollars

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times larger the World Lottery's grand prize is than Charlotte's annual salary.  $\phantom{=}\dfrac{6\cdot10^9}{3\cdot10^4}$  $=\dfrac{6}{3}\cdot\dfrac{10^9}{10^4}$

question.content: Without any equipment, you can see stars that are $2{,}800{,}000$ light-years away.  By looking through a small telescope, you can see stars that are $3{,}112{,}000{,}000$ light-years away.   **Approximately how many times as far can you see using a small telescope as without any equipment?**

hints.content: First, let's estimate how far you can see without any equipment.  $\phantom{\approx}2{,}800{,}000$ light-years  $\approx 3{,}000{,}000$ light-years  $\approx3 \cdot 10^{6}$ light-years
Next, let's estimate how far you can see using a small telescope.  $\phantom{\approx}3{,}112{,}000{,}000$ light-years  $\approx3{,}000{,}000{,}000$ light-years  $\approx3 \cdot 10^{9}$ light-years

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times farther you can see using a small telescope than without any equipment.  $\phantom{=}\dfrac{3\cdot10^9}{3\cdot10^6}$  $=\dfrac33\cdot\dfrac{10^9}{10^6}$

question.content: Santa and his elves had a workshop that allowed them to  produce $22{,}912{,}546{,}992$ toys each year.   The world population increased, so they built a new workshop. The new workshop allows them to produce $4{,}134{,}232{,}638{,}937$ toys each year.   **Approximately how many times as many toys can the new workshop produce each year compared to the old workshop?**

hints.content: First, let's estimate how many toys the new workshop can produce each year.  $\phantom{\approx}4{,}134{,}232{,}638{,}937$ toys  $\approx 4{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000$ toys  $\approx4 \cdot 10^{12}$ toys
Next, let's estimate how many toys the old workshop can produce each year.  $\phantom{\approx}22{,}912{,}546{,}992$ toys  $\approx 20{,}000{,}000{,}000$ toys  $\approx2 \cdot 10^{10}$ toys

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times more toys the new workshop can produce each year compared to the old workshop.    $\phantom{=}\dfrac{4\cdot10^{12}}{2\cdot10^{10}}$  $=\dfrac{4}{2}\cdot\dfrac{10^{12}}{10^{10}}$

question.content: James had a peach that was $98 \text{ mm}$ in diameter. One day he watered it with a magical solution, and it grew to  $188{,}869 \text{ mm}$ in diameter.  **Approximately how many times as large did the diameter of the peach become after James watered it?**

hints.content: First, let's estimate the diameter of the peach after James watered it.  $\phantom{\approx}188{,}869 \text{ mm}$  $\approx 200{,}000 \text{ mm}$  $\approx2 \cdot 10^{5} \text{ mm}$
Next, let's estimate the diameter of the peach before James watered it.  $\phantom{\approx}98 \text{ mm}$  $\approx 100 \text{ mm}$  $\approx1 \cdot 10^{2} \text{ mm}$
Now, let's divide to approximate how many times larger the diameter of the peach became after James watered it.   $\phantom{=}\dfrac{2\cdot10^5}{1\cdot10^2}$  $=\dfrac{2}1\cdot\dfrac{10^5}{10^2}$

question.content: Ten years ago, Rapunzel's hair was $19 \text{ cm}$ long.  Now her hair is $20{,}193 \text{ cm}$ long.  **Approximately how many times as long is Rapunzel's hair now as it was ten years ago?**

hints.content: First, let's estimate Rapunzel's hair length now.  $\phantom{\approx}20{,}193 \text{ cm}$  $\approx 20{,}000 \text{ cm}$  $\approx2 \cdot 10^{4} \text{ cm}$
Next, let's estimate Rapunzel's hair length ten years ago.  $\phantom{\approx}19 \text{ cm}$  $\approx 20 \text{ cm}$  $\approx2 \cdot 10^{1} \text{ cm}$
Now, let's divide to approximate how many times longer Rapunzel's hair is now than it was ten years ago.  $\phantom{=}\dfrac{2\cdot10^4}{2\cdot10^1}$  $=1\cdot\dfrac{10^4}{10^1}$

question.content: The table shown below gives the approximate $2014$ earnings for various athletes.   **Approximately how many times as large were Ronald Christian's $2014$ earnings as Forest Thorton's?**  Athlete | $2014$ earnings (in dollars)  :-: | :-:   Ronald Christian | $92{,}000{,}000$  James Leon | $20{,}300{,}000$  Mason Payton | $15{,}700{,}000$  Ryan Nader| $14{,}800{,}000$  Forest Thorton| $30{,}000$

hints.content: First, let's estimate Ronald Christian's $2014$ earnings.  $\phantom{\approx}92{,}000{,}000$ dollars  $\approx 90{,}000{,}000$ dollars  $\approx 9 \cdot 10^7$ dollars
Next, let's estimate Forest Thorton's $2014$ earnings.  $\phantom{\approx}30{,}000$ dollars  $= 3 \cdot 10^4$ dollars
Now, let's divide to approximate how many times greater Ronald Christian's $2014$ earnings were than Forest Thorton's.  $\phantom{=}\dfrac{9\cdot10^7}{3\cdot10^4}$  $=\dfrac93\cdot\dfrac{10^7}{10^4}$
$\approx 3 \cdot10^3$

question.content: The table shown below gives the estimated number of text messages sent in the U.S. by year.  **Approximately how many times as many text messages were sent in the U.S. in $2011$ as in $2005$?**  Year | Text messages sent in U.S.  :-: | :-:   $2005$ | $118{,}000{,}000{,}000$  $2007$| $577{,}000{,}000{,}000$  $2009$ | $1{,}198{,}000{,}000{,}000$  $2011$ | $2{,}357{,}000{,}000{,}000$

hints.content: First, let's estimate the number of text messages sent in the U.S. in $2011$.  $\phantom{\approx}2{,}357{,}000{,}000{,}000$ text messages  $\approx 2{,}000{,}000{,}000{,}000$ text messages  $\approx 2 \cdot 10^{12}$ text messages

First, let's estimate the number of text messages sent in the U.S. in $2005$.  $\phantom{\approx}118{,}000{,}000{,}000$ text messages  $\approx 100{,}000{,}000{,}000$ text messages  $\approx 1 \cdot 10^{11}$ text messages

Now, let's divide to approximate how many times more text messages were sent in the U.S. in $2011$ than in $2005$.   $\phantom{=}\dfrac{2\cdot10^{12}}{1\cdot10^{11}}$  $=\dfrac{2}{1}\cdot\dfrac{10^{12}}{10^{11}}$
